column3: Ember provides a solid base for ambitious applications.  Avoid reinventing the wheel or the need for a very experienced architect (who is still going to screw up anyway) and just follow community standards and best practices. The simplicity of the framework lets you write your business logic and the flexibility (addons, engines, etc...) offers elegant solution to scale your project.

column315:
More development/documentation around supporting legacy APIs that do not conform to the JSONApi spec.

Support paging in JSONApi.

While time from zero to new ember application is really short, the time it takes to actually understand ember's concepts and nuances is significantly more, especially if you are trying to accomplish tasks not part of the "out of the box" setup, like custom ember data serializer/adapter setup.

Support easier debugging of tasks that run on the backburner.

column315:
For a long time, my main gripe with ember was naming of concepts. 
What ember's call 'routes' are actually 'view controllers' (and actions in routes being 'action controllers') in the traditional MVC paradigm. View controllers in MVC are responsible for gathering up the necessary view model in terms of the concepts in the model layer when a request matching with its URI template is received and then passing it into the necessary view. This is exactly what routes do but under a different new name.
What ember called 'controllers' was actually the logical parts of the view, which with templates constitutes 'views' in the traditional MVC paradigm. Traditionally views consist of a template and optional business logic that can work on the client side. That optional view logic is what ember used to call controllers.
So legacy naming MRVC was only unnecessarily confusing and was creating its concepts where there were already applicable ones existing. The recent pattern of Model-Route-Component maps with the traditional MVC in a better way; routes being C and components being V. 
Of course this in no way hurts the developer experience but in my opinion, increases the learning curve coming from traditional server-side MVC web frameworks.

Lastly, an object model that makes use of native javascript concepts, and a production-ready fastboot are the definitive features that could let me evangelize the ember on all fronts, everywhere. I think both of them holds tremendous value to all web developers around the world.

column3:
I understand that Ember's supposed to be an opinionated framework, but it can be too rigid sometimes, and given that since ember-cli is a bit behind in terms of features compared to other tools such as webpack, that can be a bit cumbersome.
Also, the fact that the property calls are all strings makes it very error prone and very unfriendly to be used with transpilers such as Typescript.

column3:
Ember is a great choice for teams of all sizes. I have had success for over 5 years with Ember and have been able to upgrade applications over that time to latest Ember.

I also love teaching Ember since it gives a solid foundation for building front end applications and has best practices built in. It does a great job at teaching  and implementing a solid architecture.

Limitations in Ember Data, like I am unable to send multiple models in a single request. It's also hard do have a quick response without associated model so; I have to define model for single boolean result.
Very bad development tools integration (VS, VSCode are two examples of this).
Hard to integrate as part of server side applications, you can only use it smoothly if you have separate front-end application and using CLI.

column315: I already recommend Ember constantly for most of the same reasons I decided to pick it up over Angular back before either were in 1.0.0 stages. I think that the biggest thing is I wish it was a little more popular among the communities, and I'm hoping the move to npm install your way from Glimmer -> Ember becomes a reality soon and there's a new influx of people. However, while I have convinced a few people to take a look at Glimmer because of the VM ideas behind it, I have heard a few complaints that there is a lack of documentation compared to Ember (something that Ember is actually GREAT at).

column315: When looking at Ember from the outside, it looks like its dying. SEO for docs and guides, low activity on Stack Overflow, Discuss etc. The lack of availability of Slack convos etc all lead to a reasonable assumption that there's no future in Ember.  None of that has to do with Ember as a technology or methodology, and at this point it's FAR more important than adding x or y feature. It needs to look like a robust and thriving option when choosing a framework, or it's toast.

column315:
Thank you for the annual survey, it gives me a chance to thank you for the great tool that is Ember.

I code javascript in a old 'old school' way: I include ember js files the same way you would do with jquery for example.

I am not willing to use ember CLI as I don't like to compile stuff everytime I make a small change. I have a simple workflow like this: 
- amend a js file
- save it
- upload it on FTP
- refresh the browser page and check if it's all good

I have a feeling that using ember CLI will make it more complex. It seems that I have no choice anymore with the new version 3: using ember was as easy as including 2 js files in the page: the min version and the template compiler. It won't be anymore, that's an unconfortable choice.

It would be awesome if you could reconsider the choice you made and bring back compiled versions of ember ready to download.

Once again, thank you so much for doing ember, it made possible projects like www.xr.plus
( the user area is using ember as the core of a 3D editor to make web Augmented Reality content)

Thank you!

Clément
c@lune.xyz

column3: The "batteries included" methodology is a win over the React ecosystem. There were some unexpected breaking changes (2.10 - lots of double-render deprecations became actual errors). It is difficult to migrate from Ember 1.x (a world of binding) to Ember 2.x (a world of DDAU). I would still recommend Ember to a friend, because of its community and maturity.

column185:
ember-cli-less: putting styles inside addon/ instead of app/ broke things when upgrading from Ember-CLI 2.7 to 2.12

Upgrading from < 2.10 to >= 2.10: "you updated a value twice in a single run loop (didInsertElement)". We were still recovering from the migration from Ember 1.x to 2.x (binding to DDAU) and having this go from a deprecation in < 2.10 to a blocking error in 2.10 presented a bit of difficulty

column315:
Ember can still be very heavy, both in its first time developer experience and its download size. 

What makes React easy to pick up is that it's easy to create a one file project that works. Even though we know most projects don't  usually stay as one file, that's a big draw for new developers picking it up.

I can also definitely understand why some people would *not* choose to use Ember for apps where fast load times are an important priority. More priority given to build packaging and Glimmer rehydration would help a lot.

column3: As a front end js framework, it can do most things a front end dev needs. The all-in-one approach with Data, Routing, and the addon ecosystem makes it easy to get started and to be uniform with others in the Ember ecosystem. On the other hand, being so opinionated makes it hard for developers to take things piecemeal (as contrasted with, say, React + Redux or React + MobX). If you want to do things The Ember Way, that's awesome. If you have a different use case, or you aren't familiar with all of The Ember Way, it can be very frustrating.

column3: I deduct points mainly because I don't like ember data very much and feel like it should not be accompanying or recommended by default. Objects are not state and state is not objects, and many people miss that. Also, REST is overused and shoehorned way too often and only works with the simplest CRUD cases; I am more of an RPC guy and documentation emphasises these things to the point where coders (not necessarily newbies) fall into dogmatic traps while missing the point of transactions (changing multiple entities in one request ACIDly).

column315: Documentation should really reflect the problems with ED, the value of Transactions, ORMs and query Wrappers in General, and recommend caution with these topics to users who have not thought about them (but of course not force the topic; there are use cases where ED and REST do work fine. Just tell people that there are scenarios where it doesn't easily fit if data integrity is at a premium). Let Ember API docs be indexed by search engines instead of a robots.txt preventing that; documentation doesn't need to be an SPA, even though I can see the appeal for ember devs to make one :-).

column3: BrocolliJS is limiting me from doing many things that I could achieve with Webpack / Gulp. There is no Hot Module Reloading, the framework is huge and hard to learn (at first), I have no context where my components are coming from (from an addon, an addon that pulls another addon, etc.), and I have to reference a PR to figure out the different import statements I can make with the app.

column315:
- I need to know where my components are coming from (imports would be nice at some point)
- Import statements don't map to anything and my IDE has no idea where to look (import @ember/string)
- Brocolli build is very limiting and I can't do a fraction of what I could do with Gulp and Webpack. Maybe make an eject version where I could modify the build settings? If not, we need more docs + flexibility in the order of when the trees are compiled. 
- I miss hot module reloading. This is the most exciting new feature in modern web development and there doesn't appear to be a path to make this work in Ember.
- It's hard to make an ember app do more than it's advertised to do. Finding things that are outside the norm is incredibly challenging and I have to look into the actual source code to learn things
- Ember is incredibly hard to learn, but it smoothes out at some point. I feel I have to memorize my entire app to be efficient. 

I will say this, it's a large framework and maybe these are just symptoms of that, but compared to projects like Vue - I felt like I went back a few years when starting a project on Ember. If the issues are addressed above, this would have potential to be my favorite framework because I love the concept of addons and the opinionated structure of everything.

column3:
It functions, but I've used Vue, Angular 1, Ember and React, and Ember doesn't really have much that stands out.

Builds are very slow with Ember, the API has some odd missing pieces (where's the object/Map equivalent of computed('x.[]')?), the ramp up time is quite high compared to competing frameworks.

The heavy push towards JSON API doesn't help unless both UI and API are greenfield projects. Otherwise, Ember Data feels like a heavy layer for not much benefit. While you could use just window.fetch() in that case, too much of the Ember ecosystem assumes Ember Data to use that.

The Ember Inspector feels clunky compared to the Vue devtools, at least in Firefox. Let's say I want to inspect the value of myController.items[0].name -> 

I need to either:

1. Navigate to myController in the inspector
2. Send items to $E.
3. Run $E.objectAt(0].get('name')

or if items happens to be managed in Ember Data

1. Find the item type in the Ember Data list (potentially quite large
2. Manually scroll through all items to find the instance I want.

Initiative such as pods or angle components which were promoted as the future then unceremoniously cancelled or dropped.

The strict naming convention requiring so many identical names renders my jump to file feature in my editor less useful. Is foobar.js the model for foobars, the route for the foobar display page, the controller for the same, etc.

send vs sendAction, why? :(

column315:
This is a hard one, because while some of the actions would be doable (like cleaning up the APIs mentioned before), others are almost saying "Don't be Ember", which I know is a hard sell. Ember is opinionated, and a lot of these opinions aren't shared by me.  

But for a start:

Pods. Opening my models folder makes my editor lag. Resurrect these or bring an alternative to stuffing 10s or 100s of files in a folder.
Use ES6 properties instead of .get()/.set() everywhere. I understand there are steps in place for this, please don't let it end up like the initial version of pods/angle components where they got forgotten for the next shiny.
Make builds not take several minutes on larger projects.

column315:
Webdev for me at the end of the day is a wage - especially javascript dev. Would I like to use Ember instead of the others? yes of course. I think there is a small, job-secure, core ember using community in a few large companies but outside of that the perception is Ember has no future. The only logical course of action for an Ember developer therefore is to get a job at one of these (mostly american) companies or use something else.

Ember has and continues to make a tremendous contribution to innovation in the js framework space. But it's time to consider a merge a la merb and rails instead of further framework proliferation a la Glimmer.

I feel this would be the best possible result for the majority of ember devs and would be hugely beneficial for the 95% of javascript developers who don't know what Ember offers in terms of productivity.

column315:
Get the basics right - download size and boot/render performance on par with the best, instant (300ms-1s) rebuild + (hot) reloads, fewer bugs and random breakage in core (ember, cli, data), more focused effort of the core team on delivering a feature or two with the most value to framework users in each 6 week cycle instead of year long periods of "bug fix release" announcements, issues and PRs addressed quickly (in a week or two, not months/never), clear plans and communications about what is being worked on, where (GH links), and what are the realistic ETAs, so that users can help out or plan accordingly.
P.S. If you want to market the framework better, write more articles about the server-side integrations (how to set up example projects on both server and client), to align ember with more existing large coder communities (java spring boot, php symfony, drupal,  wordpress, magento, node etc.) on your official site, e.g. in Cookbook format. Vue exploded right after (just because?) it was adopted by Laravel - find and actively pursue similar opportunities.

column3:
I think Ember is great as a complete SPA solution and greatly simplifies development, architecture and the cli & toolchain remove a whole lot of pain. 

I'd rate it higher if I believed I could actually convince colleagues who are already huge fans of React / Typescript etc., to switch, but from experience, I know mostly the arguments will be that other frameworks are less opinionated and allow easier custom tooling.

So, to be fair my scoring is less of a reflection on Ember than my confidence that I could convince certain developers to adopt it.

column315:
Some ideas to make Ember better:
1. But I think for Ember to thrive long-term contributions should go up. I know LinkedIn is using it, perhaps you could work on driving more usage in Microsoft after they purchased LinkedIn? 

Typescript is already popular with Ember people, and Microsoft doesn't 'have' a framework (Google has Angular, Facebook has react). 

2. Ember has always been about 'ambitious apps', perhaps you could extend the website with 1-2 pages explaining how Ember is a great with for large companies, do a case study with LinkedIn and Intercom for example.

Aside: I was happy with this survey until the "what is your current gender identity" question. It's ironic that the people who don't want gender to matter (which is an idea that I support!) are the ones that are most obsessed about gender. 

Why not leave gender politics out of a code-related survey and focus on the technology instead?

column3: I love Ember and want to recommend it to everyone. However, I have worked on client projects in the past where the client adopted Ember on my recommendation, and later had significant trouble maintaining the project and hiring developers with enough Ember expertise to maintain the project. I think this probably is more of a hiring and training and business problem than any inherent issue with Ember, but I see choice of tech as a business decision, and although I love the community, the ecosystem, the developer ergonomics, it is becoming harder for me to recommend it in certain scenarios, particular when there is a large business trying to migrate its legacy application to a modern stack (and ramp up legacy developers tbh). A lot of it I think has to do with ramping up developers who find Ember to be a bit overwhelming to wrap their arms around or who disagree with or don't understand some aspect of Ember's conventions and then throw their arms up at the whole thing. Would love to have a better story for those developers who seem to prefer "configuration over convention".

column315: One thing I hear clients worry about is being able to hire more Ember.js developers to maintain apps using Ember.js. Their impression is that finding Ember.js developers is hard, and it's hard to counter that assertion when pointing to sheer numbers of developers who use Ember.js. Compared to developers who are familiar with React, Ember.js developers are just not as plentiful, so I think their concerns are valid. I wish there were a way of increasing the pool of developers who are using Ember.js. One thing that has me turning more and more towards Vue.js is how low the barrier to entry is. Even if it means I'm handing off a project to junior developers who don't fully understand JavaScript. I at least have confidence that they will be able to achieve some baseline level of productivity in a very short amount of time. I wish I could say the same about Ember.

column185:
My company, using ember before I joined, was a very early adopter (rocking version 1.2.2) that at time of writing is still in production. When I joined ember 2.X series had started. It was quite difficult to learn the older ember based on the guides and API. The slack community (where I ask questions when I cannot find the solution via the API/Guides) arn't very keen on answering questions about ember that is that old as well. Our ember did not use the CLI. Due to the amount of breaking changes, we decided it would be a easier to just rewrite the application in the latest version (3.0.0).

Although the materials for upgrading ember are available through various blog update posts and shifting through very old stack overflow and blog posts, there isn't a clear upgrade process for versions that old. Majority of the API docs also give a 404 which doesn't help. That being said, we're on the new ember now (3.0.0) which is currently nearly ready to be deployed.

column315:
Simplification of the mental model for Ember. 

After spending the last few months with React for the first time, I see the initial appeal - it's a vastly simply mental model. I realize that this is not entirely fair - React would be better compared to Glimmer than all of Ember.

For a sufficiently complex app, I have no doubt that an Ember implementation would be much easier to learn & maintain.

But for new or simple apps, there's overhead that is intimidating to newcomers and irksome to veterans such as myself.

Even if we only compare React to Ember's view/component layer, React is still much simpler to learn and reason about. 

And like it or not, the rest of the JS world compares React directly to Ember, and it feels futile to attempt to change that comparison. We need to do better in that comparison, not try to change everyone's mind that it's the wrong comparison to make.

column315: It is my front end framework of choice, so not much.  However, I do notice that there seems to be a lot of people around (on the internet and such) who seem to try to overlook Ember as a framework.  They mention Angular, React and Vue (etc) as the most relevant frameworks and almost seem to try to ignore Ember.  I think this largely comes down to the fact that some people resent the opinionated nature of Ember.  I personally find that to be a good thing about Ember.  So often when I have worked with React or Angular, I feel like there are many things that just aren't there in those frameworks that are present in Ember.  The learning curve for new users to Ember is pretty high I think.  I have known a number of devs that have felt that way.  However, documentation has been improving and changes have been stabilizing since the 2.0 release so those should be less prevalent problems at this point.  In my opinion, there is just so much that Ember has.  If you take just the addon eco system.  What other framework has that advanced of an eco system for community code?  None that I have found.  It's a great framework and I look forward to using it for years to come.  Hopefully it can break through the barriers of opinion and become a more widely accepted powerhouse in the market.

column3: Although in some ways Ember is spectacular, it is tightly coupled to ember-data, which unless you are using the json-api spec it's more pain than anything else. column315: Ember data has to become WAY more flexible. This can happen in one of two ways: 1. Make Ember-data be much easier to customize, mostly at the response structure level. What I mean is that the current implementation almost forces you to follow the json-api spec, whereas most of my server side code (which has been running for a while) does not. One might say the easiest way is to rewrite the server side responses to adhere to the json-api spec, but since I am using Spring Boot and there is no "easy" way to do things, and there are multiple platforms (iOS, Android and third party services) hooked into them, I do not believe I should change code that is fully tested and working just to be able to use ember. Although the convention over configuration mantra works quite well, it is too stubborn for some situations.  2. Create libraries for most server side frameworks that allow you to convert the responses in an easy way. Although this is not strictly the job of the Ember team, it is ember-data that forces you to use such a spec.

column315: I think we need more new features. Glimmer components and some of the other major new usability enhancements that've been on the roadmap for some time would be really huge in selling Ember to the wider community. We still have that reputation of being the same framework we were 4 years ago (the State of JS survey shows that most devs have used Ember and would not use again) and I think it's undeserved. We are technically making strides past many other frameworks at this point, and I think showing what Ember is now capable of will finally break that mentality.

column315:
- Fastboot has terrible documentation - tell us how to do more than just set up a "hello world" app!
- Ember's becoming more difficult to learn. eg The new modules change made Ember more difficult to use for new learners.
- Better testing support/documentation. We use the REST Serializer. Ember Mirage has been a huge pain to use, because their documentation doesn't apply when using the REST Serializer. Every step of the way involves figuring out what crazy thing we need to do to get it to work.

column3:
New to Ember, <1 year.
It has been both less + more painful than I expected.

Bunch of greenhorns taking on a very large Ember 2.12+ code base that uses a lot of non standard library and custom components with documentation.

Learning Ember Data is harder than it should be.
Learning how to do things the right way is harder than it should be.
Debugging test failures or in app errors where all you see is a vague message with a stack trace makes development harder than it should be.

The Ember Slack Community however, have always tried to help me and my team when we have asked questions, so <3
The main ember docs are good, but could be more detailed. 
The Ember api docs should have better seo, googling "ember api model reload" should take me to the docs (imo)

column315: It has a steep learning curve compared with some other frameworks I've worked with (non-JS). Making it easier to build a first, real app to gain experience and confidence would be a real plus. Also, the rate of change within Ember has felt pretty quick, which again gives the feeling of too much complexity.

column185:
bugs around deleting ember data models and immediately adding back the same model with the same id. that one is a particular sore point.

also, upgrading ember is very painful for us. we are pretty good about minimizing deprecations but every time we upgrade something comes up and the entire application breaks. upgrading our app from 2.15 to 2.18 will take a week of developer time, and that is increasingly hard to justify.

for the record, we have over 100k LOC of javascript.

column185:
I had difficulty with addons going from 2.17 to 2.18, so I stayed at 2.17.
Dropping support for IE is preventing my business from upgrading to 3.0.
I wish there were a more clear path/documentation for upgrading versions, besides just bumping the numbers in my package.json and running `yarn`. It would be really cool if ember-cli could do all of the upgrades for me (like `ember upgrade 3.0`). I don't like that I can get in a state where ember-cli, ember-data, and ember-source are running different versions.

column315: Reduced learning curve for someone new to Ember and a framework should get out of the way and let developers focus on solving business problems.  There are too many Ember updates, too many dependencies with weird names like broccoli, shim, glob, yargs and developers don't have time to learn about them all.  They should be packaged up and hidden under the covers.  Too often, we see issues on Windows about files not existing or not being able to be deleted and a repeat of the command works fine.  These are distractions and make Ember an enemy instead of an ally.

Ember is very user friendly in the beginning but when design gets complicated it is hard to know what is the correct style o preferred way of doing things.

The community is really friendly and I have always received help when needed (stackoverflow, discuss, etc).

column315: I think dismantling the mysteries behind ember's opinions by improving the learning story will go miles. For example, a JS expert on our  team with little Ember.js experience could not understand the difference between initializers and instance-initializers. I had to refer them to a thread on ember discuss because the guides and API documentation fell short. Personally, I find myself at a loss to best explain and approach debugging complex bugs within the ember ecosystem in our application. To me,  there is a gap between core team knowledge of "happy paths" and those like myself in the trenches of building products. I also think a better addon ecosystem is critical. I know glimmer provides a pared down approach to building apps, but it is hard to see why I would recommend that when react and its clones have a mature ecosystem.

column3: Depends, if they're a small startup, they will struggle with hiring like my current company. While I believe it will be a boon for productivity and enjoy using ember, we're really struggling with hiring. As a small start up we don't have as strong of a pull in hiring as we would otherwise if we went with something more mainstream like react or Vue :( That said I've used it for several years and I'm excited about the direction of ember, but the lack of ember developers makes it difficult justifying me recommending it to anyone starting a new product. For personal project I would absolutely recommend it!

While the library is nice, the unexpected change of the libraries direction has caused us a lot of pain.

column315:
1. Continue to improve performance. Ember will continue to be compared to other frameworks performance. While I think Ember's performance is good enough, developers will use performance as a reference to use something else.

2. Making importing node modules automatic. Importing node modules should be as simple as adding a package as a dependency (or devDependency) in package.json - on this note, document via blog why dependencies need to be defined as a devDependency instead of a dependency. Importing dependencies has too many steps that I think would easily deter people.

3. Ember-cli speed improvements. Complex applications are likely to have many addons which slows down ember-cli build times.

4. Identify and steal and implement more of the developer experience that React, Vue.js and other top frameworks have to offer and demonstrate, often, how the developer experience has changed and improved.

column3: Having used both React/Redux and Ember in multiple cases, I can confidently say that Ember is a no-brainer for any project with real-world stakes. Using Ember to ship an app to production is such a dramatic value-add that I can't imagine choosing to use anything else.

column3: It depends, for a weekend hackathon if people already know it, sure. But for scaling a production code base, I've got major issues with the lack of code splitting, tree shaking, non-routable components, the shotgun blast of file naming conventions that you have to follow around, and the lack of a JSX like syntax for mixing state + templating together within the same file. All of these things add a lot of overhead to exploring, managing, and reasoning about a large code base.

column3: I've been using Ember for two years and we are live in production with two Enterprise applications. My complaints are legion but as far as being able to recommend ember I would say that a confused vision is the primary concern. Ember doesn't know what it wants to be when it grows up. Are we a component based approach like react and Vue? Are we a better implementation of angular? Are we a progressive set of libraries like Vue with glimmer? Learning Ember was already a tall feat but now all these ideas are makes together and none of them executed particularly well.

column3:
Ember is a fantastic framework for getting everyone on board and up to speed with a set of standards. It currently sits a little behind in terms of interactivity with the larger JS ecosystem ( lazy loaded modules, tree shaking, standard imports ) that make it a little harder to use to do more advanced deployments. Additionally if development a mobile only app for use in low bandwidth / high latency regions it's hard to ship super tiny bundles of very specific code.
Aside from those specific concerns the documentation is A plus and the ember-cli add-on system is second to none at the moment. I have confidence that if I had to hire a developer and on-board them to my application it would be substantially different than onboarding an average developer to an average react / vue app.

column315:
Better integration with the larger JS ecosystem.

Additionally ( and this is just a wishlist type item ) but super easy to use advanced tooling for profiling and deployment would be amazing. Having an out-of-the-box app for fastboot + meta tag injection that you can just roll out and run somewhere as part of the supported experience would be pretty good. Plus better logging and reporting would be nice. Stack traces are incredibly difficult to track down. ( I am using the rollbar cli plugin and it is basically useless)
I would also like some basic support for component rendering + latency + api latency tracking.

column315:
A shallower learning curve. Ember is great! Honestly tools, speed and development environment is awesome, but getting a new team up to speed takes time. Particularly if newly adopting ember to a project. I only learnt ember because my employer invested time in weeks of training, something I may not have done on my own. 

Pluralsight and other video websites are very much lacking in decent ember tutorials, there is only one on getting started with ember 2 and nothing on more advanced topics ember-data/addon development/build process/glimmer ect. This is personally my main medium for learning, and I find  learn best through videos so having some more of these would be a way to offer more people an on-ramp. 

If an ember path could be created on pluralsight (like the react and angular paths) this would be AMAZING.

column315:
Here comes a long answer from someone who has been on the Ember train from the beginning...

For the first few years, Ember was on the bleeding edge, providing a fully featured framework that brought sanity to frontend development and overcame a lot of the limitations with Javascript and browser quirks.  It was genuinely pushing the web forward (classes and mixins, computed properties, promises, ES6, JSON:API), and it did a remarkable job with that.  And as other frameworks and tools appeared, in my opinion Ember was still the Holy Grail because it offered an opinionated holistic framework and offered "stability without stagnation".  The learning curve was steeper than competitive tools, but it was well worth it.

Fast forward to today, Ember may have pushed the web forward, but it feels like it is being left behind.  With a more mature Javascript language, evergreen browsers, transpilers letting you write modern Javascript without worrying about older browsers, async/await, and Typescript, Ember feels quite outdated at the moment.  Progress has felt very slow... or dare I say "stagnant".  I know there has been a lot of work with Glimmer 2 and module unification, but it feels like there has been little improvement in the way that Ember apps are written.  The Javascript being written does not feel like modern Javascript, when there are other frameworks that let you take advantage of Javascript classes, Typescript, async/await right out of the box.  I used Glimmerjs for a project and was hopeful that it reflected the future of what building an Ember app would become, but discussion about integration into Ember has been quiet this past year.

While Ember's adoption has always been less than others, it seems like it is left out of the conversation these days.  It would take a lot to convince a business leader to choose Ember over other competitors due to its lack of adoption and lack of a talent pool.  And because it's not being adopted, there are much fewer sponsors to help fund ongoing improvement.

Ember Data is my biggest day-to-day pain point, and it has seen very little improvement for quite some time.  The Model Data RFC seems like it is the first step to addressing some long-standing issues, but it's unclear how long it will take to implement (we've been talking about module unification for two years).

The few things I believe is keeping Ember back these days are:

* Still needing to use the Ember object model for everything instead of Javascript classes.  I've seen some blog posts about experimenting with JS classes but it does not seem to be available out of the box.  As a developer, I want to be able to write modern canonical Javascript.  Even if it is being transpiled into the Ember object model as part of the build process, I think this will go a long way to making it feel more modern.

* Support for async/await out of the box.  Again it's unclear whether or not it is.  Nobody has mentioned that it works, any chatter about has been about testing.  I use ember-concurrency and it's much better than promises, but again, baking in async/await support would be a good step forward.  Again, even if it is being transpiled along the way, it doesn't matter.

* Improve Ember Data's data flow: immutability, forking / transactions, etc.

I genuinely appreciate the work everyone has put into it.  I dabble when I can, but I have very few free cycles these days between work and family.  I want to see Ember be talked about in the same breath as React and Vue, continue to evolve as other frameworks fall in and out of fashion, and maintain market share.  It doesn't have to be the most popular, but it really needs to be more popular that it is today.  Hopefully things will be moving more quickly now that 3.0 has landed.

column3:
Best practices and concepts have changed dramatically over the past few years. While Ember has good documentation, what's often never communicated through these docs is how Ember has changed and why.  

The blog does a good job of this, but it would be better if it were codified into the docs.

column315: I usually recommend it. But depends on the team, the skillset/experience, and timeline. Just joining a startup, the 3 engineers I work with had 0 ember experience, but had some react experience, so we ended up going with react. I'd love to be working in ember because of familiarity, but I'm not sad about using react, because the primary front-end dev is a bit faster with react than I am with ember, so it made sense to go with that, and on the project i'm working mostly server-side elixir/phoenix. On my independent product i'm building I use elixir/phoenix/ember and it gives me enough power and capacity to be able to roll out features and maintain the code base front and back on my own in my spare time. So i dont know how to answer "what would it take" just spilled what i think about it, and you can interpret as you wish.

column3: It can feel a bit outdated with a lot of overhead to get up to speed. Implementing ECMAScript Classes will help with teaching Ember to newer developers who are learning the latest ES features. Ember is also quite heavy, which is a drawback for performance focused apps. I also find the Router to be difficult to work with, due to the lack of relative paths ( link-to '.child') or (link-to '^') for the parent route.

column315: Ember needs to simplify it's API and concepts, I often feel like I'm writing "Ember Code" instead of just JavaScript. When I've worked with other libraries, for example React, I feel like I'm writing Javascript and just sprinkling in the "React bits".  I think Embracing the latest ECMAScript standards, Classes, Imports/Exports, Getters and Setters, Class Decorators, could go a long way to make Ember feel modern and developer friendly. Also a focus on code optimization through a smaller package size, tree-shaking, embracing Webpack for bundling, etc. would help Ember keep up with the expectations of a "Modern Javascript Framework".

column315: More uptick in Ember mentions in the general JavaScript community when frameworks are being discussed. Currently, it seems almost be relegated to being mentioned alongside AngularJS, Knockout and even Backbone as one of the "older" frameworks. And I don't hear it mentioned alongside React, Angular or Vue as a framework to use going forward. This concerns me as I worry about maintainers moving on from the Ember ecosystem for one of the more recent frameworks, despite the strides being made by the Ember team. And the team IS doing really good things, but it does not seem to be picked up much by the larger JavaScript community. Making Ember more modular so that parts of Ember can be used without needing the entire ecosystem (the "install your way to Ember" that was heard in the 2017 EmberConf). Also, moving to a structure more like the component based structures of the other relevant JS frameworks (i.e. lose the MVC structure) would help.

column315:
1) Forms. Forms are the difference between todo apps and ambitious apps, and while ember prides itself in less developer choices, there are 39 published ways to build forms for ember.  https://emberobserver.com/categories/forms 

Rallying behind a single way to build forms would allow developers to more easily publish "complex input" widgets along with their modules. 

Most of this opinion is driven by the Drupal FAPI. Yes yes, it's php. I can only speak for my own experiences. and I can tell you I started with Drupal because forms were easy. https://api.drupal.org/api/drupal/developer%21topics%21forms_api_reference.html/7.x
https://www.drupal.org/docs/7/howtos/how-to-make-a-simple-module-with-a-form-and-menu-link

Secondly, contrib community governance. I spent 10 years or so doing Drupal work and there are many steps to ensure at somewhat rich contrib ecosystem. I know this is a greater issue in the javascript land, and not just ember, but I think if ember could figure it out it would be a big win.

The form thing is a great example, I think there should be more reasons to contribute to existing projects than reasons to make a new project trying to tackle the same problem. That concept I think flows well into ember's message, but when it comes the contrib ecosystem there are tons and tons of cases in which multiple modules compete for the same use case.

forms: 39 options
mapbox gl: 5 options
mapbox: 4 options
async buttons: 12 options (are there really that many ways to implement a single button pattern?)

I really appreciate ember observer... But I think there should be a contrib section on ember.js... with specific criteria to be listed as a recommended module of some kind. Filtering by version would also be great... I think trying to google "how to build complex forms with ember" and then finding the 39 options and half of them haven't been updated in forever is overwhelming for users.

column3:
- Too Much Lock-in
- Too many files (no single-file components)
- Routes, Controllers adds confusion
- For a batteries included framework, state management seems to be not solved
- Ember-data is a blessing and a curse

(I say this while still using and being thankful for what Ember provides us -- I know that Ember was developed in a different time, and I know this would potentially be very different if Ember was built in today's front-end environment)

column3: Ember is a comprehensive framework for building single-page apps. It can take you all the way from view-rendering up to routing, modularization, etc., etc. However, the two places where Ember falls short is in giving beginners a gradual way to get started (controllers vs. components?!) and in having EmberCLI abstract away the challenges of dependencies, version upgrades, and the other challenges of maintaining a package.json file.

Also I'm not sure what to do with Bower dependencies--Yarn sorta supports them, only some have been moved in NPM.

column315:
Reducing bundle size via all means possible.
Easy code-splitting. Engines are an interesting approach and allow for very explicit code-splitting (including vendor files). The problem is that the implementation is not very stable (bugs with FastBoot) and its design is catered towards large apps with clear-cut boundaries. There are many cases where I don't need a large component/collection of contextual components to load instantly. I'm willing to make the tradeoff of speed for a smaller initial bundle size. The ability make a component `loadable` (react-loadable) or use a webpack-style async import can be extremely useful in these cases.
Open up the component APIs to let addon developers painlessly experiment, without the stigma of touching private API. A lot of the key template helpers that enable contextual components are also locked off, like `action` and `component`. Not everything can be expressed in templates. A bit of js can go a long way.

column3: Ember allows you to get up and running very quickly. I believe the learning curve is a bit steep, but is getting better as the docs improve. Also, as things like ES5 getters, and other common syntax in vanilla JS move over, I believe the learning curve will be better. I think a lot of people cling to frameworks like React, because it is very similar to vanilla JS. I still enjoy the abstractions, macros, etc. that Ember provides. I think this has value in and of itself, that just needs to be communicated.

column315:
Module unification seems like a great improvement.

Better documentation on broccoli could be nice. For example, if I create an addon and need to merge the CSS in with the application, that seems like a very useful case that could be decently documented. I believe there's currently a high barrier to entry for new addon devs who want to create an addon, but aren't sure how some of these build hooks work. I understand you can't document all of the cases, but I think there's a balance that could be struck.

Code splitting to decrease /dist size sounds great too, and know that's in the pipeline.

All in all, I believe delivering the current items on the status board would be a great improvement for Ember. Additional documentation to help new devs contribute via addons could be another great improvement.

Guys, first of all; awesome work!!! This is just the best framework that I have ever seen. The way one gets up and running with SPA apps is just too good.

One thing that I would love to see going forward is; “Ember components to be by default one way binded”. More like react components. Currently we make efforts to make our components one way binded (readonly, json parse). You see it’s a simple mental model when the size of the project grows.

This is the only thing that I would love from the ember community.

Thank you thank you thank you!!

column315:
Here comes a long answer from someone who has been on the Ember train from the beginning...

For the first few years, Ember was on the bleeding edge, providing a fully featured framework that brought sanity to frontend development and overcame a lot of the limitations with Javascript and browser quirks.  It was genuinely pushing the web forward (classes and mixins, computed properties, promises, ES6), and it did a remarkable job with that.  And as other frameworks and tools appeared, in my opinion Ember was still the Holy Grail because it offered an opinionated holistic framework and offered "stability without stagnation".  The learning curve was steeper than competitive tools, but it was well worth it.

Fast forward to today, Ember may have pushed the web forward, but it feels like it is being left behind.  With a more mature Javascript language, evergreen browsers, transpilers letting you write modern Javascript without worrying about older browsers, async/await, and Typescript, Ember feels quite outdated at the moment.  Progress has felt very slow... or dare I say "stagnant".  I know there has been a lot of work with Glimmer 2 and module unification, but it feels like there has been little improvement in the way that Ember apps are written.  The Javascript being written does not feel like modern Javascript.

Its adoption seems much less than others these days, and it would take a lot to convince a business leader to choose Ember over other competitors due to its lack of adoption and lack of a talent pool.

column3: Overall I feel that Ember is in a really good and stable place right now with plenty of new features being added in over time. I greatly appreciate ember-cli, because finding all the right parts to make a running app is not for me.

column315: The biggest gripe I hear about is the documentation.  We have a lot of built up internal knowledge, but we are struggling to find good sources of information on the more advanced topics within Ember.  Broccoli, Ember-CLI Addon/Engine development and even the built in helpers like input/link-to have incredibly little detailed documentation around them and their features and application.  Mostly we have to search the internet for articles or discussions on the topic and are often left feeling adrift without a reliable source of truth on these topics.  Ultimately this erodes my confidence in the future of Ember because I'm concerned of how little documentation there is relative to other larger mind-share projects within the JavaScript community.

column3:
It's a great ecosystem. I like the well thought out architecture (Router, Ember-Data, Add-ons, engines, ...). It really helped me becoming a better JavaScript developer after reading some of your code. Also I really appreciate how the render engine was improved over time without me having to change my code too much.

Anyhow, recently a couple of things I got used to in React like: hot reloading, Mobx and TypeScript support are things I now miss a little bit in Ember.

column3: no built in hot reloading, no built in discrete state management (cough cough redux/cerebrum), `this` is used across the whole app, pseudo globally, but is always going to be something different depending on where you are. There are private properties you can access, but maybe shouldn't, but you never really know which ones are actually a-ok. It's object oriented, and is therefore far more complex than a functional language+framework. It's very hard to re-use code. Handlebars actually sucks, designers can't know what variables they can use, I don't know any "designers" that use handlebars, yet it seems to be targetted towards them. The audience seems to be ruby/rails type people that want to keep logic out of their templates, which is historically a respectable goal, but this goal is not even achieved. JSX is actually extremely usable and improving every day. There is support for compilation to incremental dom, which has the same architecture as glimmer. Oh, and the object model. .get('this') or/and set(this, 'crap'..). Idk if it's ever been beginner friendly, but it doesn't seem to be getting better. But, maybe it was ember that has made me understand and appreciate the simply functional approach.

column3:
Really love the convention over configuration which can make the learning curve of Ember a lot kinder. I graduated from a bootcamp which taught Rails (GA) and so a lot of my friends are coming from Rails as well. There are a lot of really lovely similarities between Rails & Ember which made it a lot easier to pick up for me!
Also the community is amazing! Always able to have questions answered and feel supported.

column3:
I would have been a 9-10 several years ago. 

This project has stagnated way too much.  And not in a good stable way like one would expect. We are on ember 2.17 but we cant upgrade past ember-data 2.12 due to all of the unaddressed (not even responded to) issues

At this point if our ember app wasn't so large, we would throw it away and rewrite it.

Fixing the bugs in ember-data
Reducing the asset load delivered to browser
Engines being in a stable state
A revived community

I have to be honest. Even with all of the above I probably can't recommend Ember. I feel like it is a dead project. When picking technology for a real B2B application, it is important to have the prospect of a future. I don't think Ember has one.

column315:
Ember has made great progress with targeted module imports for specific Objects (as opposed to "import Ember from 'ember'). Also, the ability to access properties and computeds without the this.get(..) and this.set(..) methods is a step in the right direction.

What would be great, would be if the Ember could use classes instead of the Route.extend(..) and Component.extend(..) construct, and also if angle components (e.g. Glimmer components) could be used in Ember. This would make Ember feel more modern and less confusing when introducing people to Ember.

Angular 5 has built-in CSS isolation for Components. Ember has the ember-component-css addon which works great. Would be great if Ember could have built-in CSS isolation for Components as well.

column315: An easy answer for data. We use Ember Data, and it works, but when it doesn't it can be hellish (mostly around relationships and computed properties) and it just feels like there has to be a better answer. Glimmer Components in Ember are going to be magical. Tree-shaking would be cool. A first-class approach to Fastboot would be awesome too. It works, it's impressive, but it still feels like I'm building a different type of app when I use it (I GET IT, TRUST ME) but it's friction. I've always wanted to use Ember for static site generation (maybe I should look at Prember?) but yeah, I think that's everything. I love Ember, it's a great tool for building all sorts of JS apps and it attracts the nicest, and least douchey people.

column315:
The ember community seems to be comprised of experts and novices.  At best, the experts are providing 'all the answers' to novices. The novices have been looking for a framework that enables them to do more than they can on their own. The experts listen to their needs and push forward.

The reality feels _much_ messier; more like a personality cult. The ember community tries very hard to get people involved and contributing, but it still feels like there are those that _know_...and everyone else. If you haven't been part of the discussion before its public, you're just going to be behind, and probably 'incorrect' with your opinions. I think embereños generally has a weird smugness and chip on its shoulder, for some reason. I do believe the leadership _is_ trying to make the best framework possible and demand more of the internet. Unfortunately, it seems like there's an over emphasis this (and a lot of self-congratulation for trying), and not as much focus on how to actually use it to build ambitious products.

But all the glimmer stuff feels like noise because the core team is afraid of React.

column315: Massively better debugability. Less magic. More transparency in async operations. Less testing confusion. Entirely different default data layer. Almost all async behaviors — especially when setting data that results in a UI change — go through so many layers of abstraction that they are impossible to debug. Error messages often state cause without any reference to the source. All of these things make Ember incredibly difficult to develop on when things haven't gone quite right.

column315:
There's a few things...
1) Ember Data, and it's role in the route lifecycle, seems to struggle with anything more than trivial applications.  The nature of modern crud apps is lots of relational data, and both retrieving and saving relational data is pretty tricky to do right.
2) Ember is heavy-weight.  The modules RFC is awesome here, and much needed.  Also, Ember Engines are difficult to use compared with Angular's simple config for lazy loading routes.  Lazy loading needs to be much simpler.
3) The lack of an "Ember Native" is killing us.  Cordova wrapped Ember does not cut it for those expecting a slick mobile experience.  Neither do PWAs.  Which leaves us looking at React Native, Xamarin, etc - all of which we do so really reluctantly due to the lack of Ember support.  I'd be so excited with Ember support in this area.

column315:
The performance would have to improve greatly. Smaller bundle sizes, less execution blocking, tree-shaking, etc. Also, a smaller API would be nice. I think Glimmer components will help with this a lot, but when will they be feasible for production?

Which is another point: Ember must iterate faster. We're just now talking about tree-shaking, es6 classes, individual module imports, spreadable attributes, etc. where other frameworks have enjoyed these features for years. It feels like Ember is always playing catch-up rather than leading the field. If I'm a developer choosing a framework/library, I don't want the one that is perpetually just behind the curve. Don't get me wrong, Ember has lots of strengths, but it falls behind in key areas that are very important to developers.

It also seems that some features are left half-baked, like engines. Engines "work" but they don't have good developer ergonomics. For example, you can't use many editor plugins with engines, because they can't resolve the paths. Don't get me started on the Ember resolver. Why can't we just have relative imports that are easy to reason about and understand? Too much magic.

I'm not placing blame on the community or anyone for Ember's shortcomings, but when asked what it would take for me to recommend it over some of the other fantastic options available today the short answer is "a  lot". If I had to recommend a general approach to follow for improvements, it would be to move as close to web standards as possible. I think devs want to move away from esoteric frameworks and more towards vanilla js and web components. Glimmer components is a good first step, now we just need to execute on that quickly!

column3:
Ember has some baggage, and the community is making great steps towards removing it and streamlining the framework, but on the whole it feels slightly dated to me after using others. (this.get, computed properties vs just functions, not just using classes). I'm also no longer sold on Ember Data and would prefer just using fetch, etc in model hooks. Finally, debugging is so much harder than other frameworks due to the run loop.

All of that said, the conventions are still wonderful and allow users to be productive, so that's the area I recommend most.

column315: I already feel great about recommending Ember. The "stability without stagnation" mantra is most important in this regard. The ember team's dedication to bringing the latest technology/ideas to the framework, and giving it to existing apps either for free or via a doable path has been great. As long as I trust that this will continue in the future, I will continue to recommend Ember. The friendly, inclusive, and responsive community is super important too :-)

column315: Better docs. Both the main tutorials, and the framework documentation proper, are remarkably poor, worse than any other framework I've used and I've used a fair few. The tutorials are very limited in scope and don't cover practical/realistic use patterns. The documentation proper isn't searchable over any version except the most recent LTS. And the overall design and layout is just kind of user hostile. Oh, and there's simply NO tutorial for ember-data.  And, the framework code is spread over a ton of repos, so trying to figure out how something works by reading the source is rarely a viable option.

column315: Ember needs to deliver long promised features that can compete with other modern frameworks. When I talk to people from other frameworks, they say that Ember is behind at least a year on things that they have, such as Code splitting, Tree Shaking, good and robust SSR, easy integration with things like GraphQL, including third party libraries using NPM without a shim, etc. Also the query params in routes and controllers are a mess, it becomes very difficult to maintain and explain to people how to work with that, a router refactor (to kill controllers) would be very welcome. Other things that Ember is working on, but still not 100% is ES classes and setters (we got getters!). Single file components would be very interesting and compelling for the folks coming from Vue and React, as they are used to not have multiple files per component. We also need more Ember developers to be able to sell to our managers that Ember is a good choose, as per hiring can be difficult and not as attractive as using Vue or React.

column3: While I understand that the Ember community puts a lot of work in to documentation and I understand the merits of convention over configuration I find that Ember seems to deal in a good deal of "magic". I find it hard to get up and running with simple concepts and even harder to keep up with more advanced concepts which seem to be kept within a smaller circle. I'm often given the advice to "join the slack channel" which should not be necessary to understand best practices.

column3: I met Ember in 2015 and use it since 2016. Implemented in a startup that I worked on: https://www.mlabs.com.br/ and the experience was fantastic. Then I moved to a company that does software consulting for Embraer (the largest aircraft manufacturer in Latin America), when I entered the stack there was AngularJS and quickly saw how much the teams suffered with standards, where each project followed in a way. I have also implemented Ember and am still on the path to evangelize him here, adoption has been well received and we are reaping good fruit. I always had a lot of help when I needed it, especially in Ember's Slack. Much still remains to be done, for it is still difficult to find new content about Ember. But I also tired of complaining about this and doing nothing, soon I hope to write some posts about my experience in these 2 years with Ember and also technical posts.

column315:
There are better examples of real cases of Ember use. "Hello worlds" are cool, but they are not practical to show new people what they can really take advantage of Ember.

There are many, many, but many problems in many places (Ember, Ember-Data, Ember-Cli) that were opened a long time ago, with users recently asking "Any update on this?" This is very frustrating. And I fully understand that it is a lot and sometimes people are lacking to take these issues and either resolve or respond to someone else. But it's still a problem.

Could have a place in Ember with Addons indicated by the main staff. The complements we know are essential to use on 90% of Ember's projects. This will also help (I think) that other users knowing the existence of these addons may help the addons themselves. Some addons: Ember-Simple-Auth, Ember-Cli-Mirage and some internationalization complement (I quote below).

It would be great if there was an internationalization session with Ember. Both via YAML and via EndPoints. Even if this is something made available by a third party add-on, which application does not have to be internationalized today? Many and many. If I was a new user of Ember and tried to choose between Ember, React and Angular and I had this information in Ember it would be much easier to choose.

I'd like to do more than I'm talking about here. Just talking is easy. Talk is cheap, show me the code haha. This year I will be working more with Ember fulltime and I hope to have some time to return to Ember what he has given me.

If you want to look for me to know more, I'm in Ember's slack as danilovaz :)

column315: If Ember were modernized. If you compare emberjs.com to Vue, React, Tailwind, Laravel, etc., any other myriad of open-source projects, it looks and *feels* dated. The UX and onboarding - from the site, to the tutorial, to the guides - feels old, and like there's not much care put into it. Compare this to the other frameworks, and it makes it hard (even embarrassing) to  show Ember to a modern JS developer.

column3: It's a great framework, but there are several issues that knock it down a few notches. In the 2.x series, there have been many breaking changes between minor versions despite assurances to the contrary. Documentation could be better. And finally, it is difficult to build very large applications composed of many Ember engines and addons. One major issue is that of dependency management. All engines and addons must agree on the versions of other dependencies (including Ember addons) that they consume. Which means that if engine A wants to upgrade to addon 3.0, engines B, C, D, and E must make that same upgrade in lockstep. These engines and addons may involve different teams, adding to the major headache.

column3:
ember-cli is a terrible build tool. Broccoli is cool and all but nowadays if your build tool isn't build a module dependency graph via es modules you're way behind. ember-data is dead, I opened an issue with a bug that's blocking us from upgrading beyond 2.12 back in mid-december, it has received zero response from anyone affiliated with ember. The _base twiddles_ for ember-data are broken, how do things get that bad?

Oh yeah, and ember-engines has received almost no updates in forever, so we can't code-split our huge app. Even at that point, the rest of the js community is miles ahead of simple route-based code splitting. ember-cli has loads of catching up to do. 

If our app wasn't so huge, we would have thrown it away and rewritten in react/preact long ago.

column315:
Given ember's backwards compatibility guarantee's, I believe this will be impossible. Regardless, here are some thoughts:
- Engines is a terrible solution for code-splitting. Code-splitting needs to not be route-based, and not use addons. The entire thing feels overarchitected, hard to set up, hard to understand, and for no gain over other solutions.
- ember-data is incredibly buggy and the code is impossible to understand. It's maintainers seem to have jumped ship (or they've chosen to ignore me, I'm not sure which is worse). 
- Tom Dale standing up at ReactiveConf and getting all smug about having bytecode templates (not even landed after all this time??) is depressing. Ember apps can't even code split, so I could have all the bytecode templates in the world and sites that use webpack would still load faster.
- Tom Dale being smug and calling himself a "thoughtleader." I mean come. on. 
-
 https://twitter.com/tomdale/status/954317858493759488

Even with all this, I don't think I could recommend Ember. We're in a new era of web dev, one that doesn't need ember anymore. Based on what I've seen, ember can either catch up with the rest of the js community, or it can keep it's backwards compat guarantees.

column3:
There are lots great parts of Ember which make me happy. Lots of frustrating parts are constantly getting better. However there are few long-standing issues which is important to note: 
 - There is a really big gap in the routing system. The most awful things I've ever made with Ember was routing related hacks. I believe there are types of applications which are unreasonably difficult to implement due to routing bugs and limitations.
 - Controllers. They just feel redundant.

column3: Ember is robust and the community is great, but the SEO for official Ember docs is horrible. I know that sounds stupid, but it is EXTREMELY difficult to Google relevant Ember API info, and Google is often how users first explore a technology. Not having good Google voodoo DOES matter. The SEO for the API docs right now is almost nonexistent.

column315:
Better SEO for the docs. Fewer 404 links in the docs. Better discoverability for Ember docs from search engines.

If you google "Ember computed property" right now, look at the results. They're horrible. An old API doc, and two outdated guides. 

Better yet, google "Ember readonly". There is only one emberjs hosted result in the first view results, and it is for Ember.View, and the link is broken. UGGGGGGGH.

I'm sure you take this issue seriously, but the docs have had horrible SEO since I started using Ember ~1.5 years ago. Vue, React, and Angular do not suffer from these issues. I don't think it is sufficient to tell someone to bookmark the URL of the Ember API docs.

People expect to be able to use Google to find docs. 
I know the team has a lot of priorities, but please dedicate time to this.

Even using the in-page search for something like "currentRouteName" doesn't work. That's a well defined property on the RouterService and your own internal search tool can't find it, and Google can't either. The search results for "Ember currentRouteName" are useless.

This is really frustrating to me, and I am having a really hard time convincing my employer that Ember was a good decision considering how difficult it is to find relevant documentation. I trudged through to learn Ember, but I am going to have an uphill battle convincing new devs to use it at my company, and our senior team is frowning at Ember considering the state of the docs.

Sorry, I know a lot of time goes into the docs, but this is a very real problem.

Does Google's webmaster tools complain? Can you add a sitemap? What does "Fetch & Render" as Googlebot show? Is it failing to render parts of the UI and so can't crawl the site? Can you canonical ALL docs to /release/ ?

Same issue applies not just for API docs. Try searching for "ember component lifecycle" or "ember route lifecycle". Irrelevant docs show up first and foremost.
